U.S. stocks slumped on the last trading day of the year on Friday, led down by Apple and other big tech stocks, but major indexes still posted solid gains in 2016.

In subdued holiday trading, the S&P 500 declined for a third consecutive session.

But the benchmark index still tallied an annual gain of 9.5 percent. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 13.4 percent for 2016, even as it recorded its first weekly decline since the U.S. election on Nov. 8.

Stocks stalled this week after surging in the wake of Donald Trump's presidential election. Investors have bet Trump will cut taxes and regulations and introduce fresh economic stimulus.

"It's been such a significant run-up that there's been a pause," said Bucky Hellwig, senior vice president at BB&T Wealth Management in Birmingham, Alabama. "We are to the point now where there's uncertainty with regard to what policies are implemented, when are they implemented and how are they going to affect the economy as a whole and industries specifically."

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 57.18 points, or 0.29 percent, to 19,762.6, the S&P 500 lost 10.43 points, or 0.46 percent, to 2,238.83 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 48.97 points, or 0.9 percent, to 5,383.12.

The Dow slipped further from the 20,000 milestone, after coming within 13 points of the mark but not yet breaching it.

The Dow is now up about 8 percent since the election.

"It's been quite a rally, so not surprised to see some profit taking," said Tim Ghriskey, chief investment officer with Solaris Asset Management in New York.

"There might be some reality setting in that a lot of this rally is based on assumptions of stimulus legislation occurring, and it's really the market's hope that those actions occur and that there isn't a heated battle and a water down of some of these indicated proposals by the soon-to-be new administration," Ghriskey said.

Apple shares fell 0.8 percent after a report that the company will trim iPhone production. Shares of Apple suppliers such as Cirrus Logic and Qualcomm also declined.

Tech was the worst-performing major S&P sector, falling 1 percent. Big tech names such as Microsoft and Alphabet slumped more than 1 percent.

Investors are wary that the market could be primed for a spill to start 2017, after the S&P 500 posted a surprisingly strong gain in 2016.

In other corporate news, OPKO Health shares fell 18.8 percent after the company said its experimental drug for growth hormone deficiency in adults failed to provide a statistically significant benefit in a late-stage study.

About 5.6 billion shares changed hands in U.S. exchanges, below the 6.8 billion daily average over the last 20 sessions.

Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 1.23-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.49-to-1 ratio favored decliners.

The S&P 500 posted 1 new 52-week high and 1 new low; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 58 new highs and 48 new lows.

urn:contentItem:5NWP-MN01-JBVM-Y35G-00000-00Wall St falters as key health vote delayed;NEW YORK REPORT2017-06-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 14Wall St falters as key health vote delayedNEW YORK REPORT

THE TECH-HEAVY Nasdaq led a broad Wall Street decline yesterday with stocks falling more sharply after a healthcare bill was delayed in the US Senate, raising fresh questions about President Trump's domestic agenda.

The benchmark S&P 500 posted its biggest one-day drop in about six weeks and closed at its lowest point since 31 May.

Major indexes extended losses after US Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell decided to put off a planned vote on a bill to dismantle the Affordable Care Act until after the Senate's 4 July recess.

The healthcare legislation, which has encountered resistance from several Republicans, is the first plank of Trump's domestic policy agenda, with investors eager for him to move onto his other plans including tax cuts, infrastructure spending and deregulation.

Promises for such domestic polices helped fuel a 13.1-per cent rise for the benchmark S&P 500 since Trump's 8 November election.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 98.89 points, or 0.46 per cent, to 21,310.66, the S&P 500 lost 19.69 points, or 0.81 per cent, to 2,419.38 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 100.53 points, or 1.61 per cent, to 6,146.62.

Big tech names weighed most heavily on the S&P 500. Google parent Alphabet fell 2.5 per cent after EU antitrust regulators hit the tech giant with a record $2.7bn (£2.1bn) fine.

The Nasdaq had its worst day since a tech-led slide on 9 June raised questions about the sector.

Yesterday, the tech sector pulled back 1.7 per cent. It remains the bestperforming major group this year. The healthcare sector weakened after news of the vote delay, and ended down 0.9 per cent.

Financials were the only sector to end in positive territory, rising 0.5 per cent.

Data showed consumer confidence for June rose more than expected.

urn:contentItem:49R6-5F90-01VR-906J-00000-00Wall St. flies despite United woes2002-08-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisASIAWall St. flies despite United woesAlexandra Twin; CNN/Money Staff Writer

U.S. stocks staged a strong recovery by the close of trade Wednesday, reversing earlier losses on strength in computer hardware, software, chips and retail and a reversal in Treasurys, with money flowing out of bonds and into equities.

Wednesday is also the day by which almost 700 CEOs of leading companies must certify their financial results. The executives have until 5:30 p.m. ET to do so.

The Nasdaq composite index gained 65.02, or 5.1 percent, to reach 1,334.30. The Dow Jones industrial average added 260.92, or 3.1 percent, to close at 8,743.31; it had been down more than 120 points earlier in the day.

The Standard & Poor's 500 index added 35.41, or 4 percent, to end the day at 919.62.

Treasury prices gave back much of their early gains, although the 10-year note yield still was at multi-decade lows of 4.10 percent. The yield fell below 4 percent earlier before bouncing up. The rotation out of Treasurys boosted equities.

"I didn't see anything fundamental to turn us around. I think it's a combination of program buying and asset reallocation," said Tim Heekin, head of stock trading at Thomas Weisel Partners.

"Bonds finally showed a little reversal. We put in a high on the long-terms and then dipped off of that. I think the big bond funds came in and started taking profits after the recent run. The real test will be if we can hold these levels."

Traders said the stock turnaround was also partly due to short-covering, the process in which investors who have sold shares short to take advantage of a falling market buy them back.

Big tech companies, such as Sun Microsystems (SUNW: up $0.51 to $4.44) and Oracle (ORCL: up $0.96 to $10.05), boosted the Nasdaq on no discernable news, while gains in tech names such as Microsoft (MSFT: up $2.66 to $49.71) and IBM (IBM: up $3.02 to $74.92) helped push the Dow higher.

Retailers also experienced a recovery after Dow component Wal-Mart Stores (WMT: up $3.91 to $52.62) made a late-day announcement that it will buy back up to $5 billion of outstanding shares, a move often seen as a vote of corporate confidence. The No. 1 retailer also said it will expense stock options.

According to a regulatory filing made public Tuesday, computer hardware maker and Dow component IBM (IBM: up $3.02 to $74.92) said it is cutting more than 15,600 jobs, beyond what had been expected, in its computer-services and microelectronics businesses.

Shares of Network Appliance (NTAP: up $1.95 to $9.00) rallied after the data storage computer maker posted a quarterly profit Tuesday and forecast a modest rise in revenue in the current quarter.

Chip equipment maker Applied Materials (AMAT: up $0.96 to $14.42) said it earned 7 cents a share in its third quarter, 2 cents better than estimates and in line with results a year earlier. The company also warned that orders in the current quarter could drop as much as 15 percent. The news had knocked the stock lower earlier in the day, but it recovered in the broader tech surge.
 
UAL may file for bankruptcy

Stocks in the aviation sector continued to suffer Wednesday in the fallout from US Airways bankruptcy filing earlier this week. The New York Stock Exchange has suspended trading of the stock.

After the close of trade, United Airlines parent UAL (UAL: down $0.29 to $2.45) said that it may be forced to file for bankruptcy court protection in the fourth quarter, barring any last-minute cash infusion that could help it deal with its mounting debt.

Fellow airlines, as well as companies that deal in aerospace and defense such as Dow components Boeing (BA: down $0.71 to $36.35) and United Technologies (UTX: down $1.12 to $61.35), traded lower.

Late in the session, United Technologies reaffirmed 2002 earnings per share of $4.40, a penny better than estimates. But the stock remained a notable Dow laggard.

"Conventional wisdom was that this down cycle with commercial airlines was going to bottom this year. But with US Air declaring bankruptcy, UAL in danger and American scaling back, it's become pretty clear that bottoming is going to be delayed," said Robert Norfleet, an aerospace and defense analyst with Davenport & Co.

"The fear is that orders from these companies will be deferred, delayed or cancelled and that this will negatively impact future profits at the companies that deal in production and parts, which is why these stocks have been down all week," he added.
 
CEO certification deadline

Wednesday is the final day by which 697 CEOs must certify the results of their most recent quarter, a new policy set up to reassure investors after the spate of accounting and corporate governance concerns that have plagued markets for months.

Officially, 316 CEO certifications are outstanding, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission Web site.

However, the SEC is not able to update its Web site immediately after the filings; the unofficial number of outstanding companies that are both listed and not bankrupt is approximately 71, a far smaller number. In addition, it may not be known immediately how many companies failed to certify on time, as they can get a five-day extension with a request made Thursday.

One of the concerns about the CEO certifications has been the potential for companies to restate results. A number of companies fulfilled that fear Wednesday morning.

On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve released its latest interest rate decision and economic commentary. The central bank acknowledged the economic slowdown by changing its bias to one of weakness from neutral, but also left interest rates unchanged at 1.75 percent, a move seen by some market participants as disappointing.

"The Fed's choice to hold rates steady was no big surprise. People may have been using that as an excuse to sell at the top of a trading range," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Global Partners Securities. "And we're probably going to be in a bit of a trading range until we get some new economic data that makes people want to move one way or the other."

In the day's economic news, June business inventories rose 0.2 percent, more than the 0.1 percent increase forecast of economists surveyed by Briefing.com. While the news was seen as positive, it appeared to have little impact on trade.

urn:contentItem:5S12-R3D1-JBJ7-N21P-00000-00Wall St plunges to start quarter2018-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisWall St plunges to start quarterTimothy Moore

Australian stocks appear set to open flat, though a plunge on Wall Street could muddy the waters. RBA decision ahead.

Australian stocks appear set to open flat, though a plunge on Wall Street could muddy the waters. RBA decision ahead.

Shares tumbled in New York at the start of the second quarter, as nerves frayed with President Donald Trump's continuing assault on Amazon as well as China's retaliatory tariffs on a range of US-made products.

The tech sector was particularly hard hit, extending losses triggered by Facebook's recent user data scandal.

The Dow was 682 points lower at 2.26pm local time in New York, with 29 of its 30 components down. The biggest losers: Intel, Cisco, Walmart and Nike.

Today's Agenda

Local data: AiG perf of manufacturing March, CoreLogic house prices March, ANZ job ads March, RBA board meeting and cash rate decision???

Overseas data: Euro zone Markit manufacturing PMI March, UK Markit/CIPS services PMI March

Market Highlights

SPI futures up 10 points or 0.2% to 5746 at 4.25am AEST

AUD -0.3% to 76.54 US cents

On Wall St, about 2.25pm: Dow -2.7%, S&P 500 -3.1%, Nasdaq -3.1%

In New York, BHP -2% Rio -0.8% Atlassian -0.8%

European markets closed on Monday

Spot gold +1.4% to $US1343.45 an ounce

Brent crude -2.3% to $US67.76 a barrel

US oil -2.9% to $US63.08 a barrel

Iron ore +1.2% to $US65.80 a tonne

Dalian iron ore +0.9% to 452 yuan

LME closed on Monday

10-year bond yield: US 2.72%, Germany 0.49%, Australia 2.60%

From Today's Financial Review

Exclusive: Trade war worse than 2009 recession: A global trade war would tip much of Europe, the UK, and Canada into recession and cost as many as 285,000 Australian jobs, according to KPMG.

Chanticleer: Is Blue Sky 'missing' $2.5b?: Investors in Blue Sky Alternative Investments will have a stark choice on Tuesday - either believe the company, which says it has $4 billion in audited fee earning assets, or trust Glaucus Research, who say it has $1.5 billion.

Tech stock plunge a 'speed bump', not bubble: Big tech stocks face risks from tighter regulation, trade skirmishes and an end to ultra-low interest rates, but Silicon Valley will dominate the economy for years to come.

United States

A selloff in technology majors deepened on Monday, wiping out the tech-heavy Nasdaq index's gains for the year and pushing the benchmark S&P 500 below a closely watched technical level for the first time in nearly two months.

"Failure to hold the 200-day (moving average on S&P 500) has put downward pressure on the market," said Ryan Larson, head of US equity trading, RBC Global Asset Management in Chicago. "As fundamentals tend to take a back seat, technicals are a few of the indicators that people hold on to in period of extreme volatility."

The ISM said its index of national factory activity in the US slipped to a reading of 59.3 last month from 60.8 in February. A separate report from the Commerce Department showed construction spending edged up 0.1 per cent in February after being unchanged in January.

Gross domestic product growth estimates for the January-March quarter are mostly below a 2 per cent annualised rate. The economy grew at a 2.9 per cent pace in the fourth quarter.

Tesla was reported to be making 2000 of its Model 3 sedans per week, enough to ease stock market nerves around billionaire Elon Musk's electric car maker, according to tech website Jalopnik, citing an email from Musk to employees. Tesla shares recovered from an 8 per cent loss before the Jalopnik report filtered into markets to trade down 3.5 per cent on the day.

Europe

Most markets remained closed on Monday for the Easter break with trading set to resume on Tuesday.

Asia

Asian stocks began the new quarter on Monday with mild gains.

MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.3 per cent.

South Korea's KOSPI gained 0.6 per cent and Japan's Nikkei advanced 0.6 per cent. Hong Kong's Hang Seng added 0.3 per cent and Shanghai was up 0.4 per cent.

China slaps tariffs on US in warning shot to Trump: China strikes back against US tariffs on steel and aluminium with imposts of its own.

Currencies

Patience defines RBA rate stance: The Reserve Bank is expected to reaffirm that it's still in no rush to raise interest rates when its policymakers meet on Tuesday.

Commodities

The LME was closed on Monday for the Easter break.

Shanghai base metal prices made a positive start to the second quarter. Of the five key Shanghai base metals, only nickel rose in the first quarter, while copper and aluminium posted double-digit losses.

The most-traded May copper contract on the Shanghai Futures Exchange (ShFE) closed up 0.8 per cent at 50,390 yuan ($US8028.62) a tonne. Earlier in the session, it touched 50,600 yuan a tonne, its highest since March 23. ShFE aluminium ended up 1.9 per cent at 13,990 yuan a tonne, its highest close since March 20, bouncing back from a 17-month low seen on Friday.

Chicago Mercantile Exchange hog futures tumbled to their lowest in 16 months, hit by news that China raised tariffs on US pork by up to 25 per cent in response to higher duties on Chinese steel and aluminium by the United States.

Chinese steel futures rose for a fifth straight day on Monday amid expectations that demand in the world's top consumer of the building material will pick up along with construction activity, but prices came off the day's peaks.

Steelmaking raw materials iron ore, coking coal and coke also pared gains after rising as much as 7.6 per cent earlier in the session.

Along with hopes of a recovery in demand, production curbs in China's key steel city of Handan had helped spur prices early in the day as authorities sustained the fight against pollution.

The most-active rebar on the Shanghai Futures Exchange closed up 0.6 per cent at 3344 yuan ($US533) a tonne, after surging as much as 4.7 per cent to a nearly two-week high of 3480 yuan.

"I believe demand will pick up from the first half of April as the construction season gets underway so consumption of steel products will increase," said a Beijing-based trader.

Stocks of iron ore at China's ports reached a record high of 161.68 million tonnes on Friday, up 9 per cent this year, according to data tracked by SteelHome consultancy.

While iron ore prices have generally followed the trend in the steel market, traders say the mountain of stocks of the raw material at China's ports remain a major headwind, keeping sentiment bearish.

"Even as winter production cuts in China draw to a close and blast furnaces are gradually resuming operation, there has not been any big restocking demand as most mills are choosing to draw down on iron ore stocks built earlier," the Singapore Exchange said in a report.

Australian Sharemarket

Australian shares on Thursday wrapped up their worst March quarter performance since the GFC on a suitably sour note despite a modest rebound in the major banks.

The S&P/ASX 200 index slipped 33 points, or 0.6 per cent, to 5759 on the final session before the Easter break, bringing the losses for the year to 306 points, or 5 per cent. Investors have only suffered two worse March quarters over the past 25 years - a 15 per cent plunge in 2008 and a 6.3 per cent loss in 1994.

urn:contentItem:5WTD-XKC1-JC8V-42VP-00000-00WALL STREET AND SILICON VALLEY FACE OFF2019-08-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisPg. 3WALL STREET AND SILICON VALLEY FACE OFFKevin McCauley

Apple Pay and Google Pay own the digital wallet market. Amazon and Alibaba have already loaned billions of dollars. And Facebook wants you to use Messenger to pay your friends back for dinner. Make no mistake, Silicon Valley tech giants are climbing into the financial services playground.

In the decade following the recession we've seen fintech startups precipitate incremental change in the financial services space. Disruptors have reimagined components of the financial services puzzle and nudged Wall Street into the digital age, creating the competition necessary to force traditional financial companies to compete on multiple fronts: product innovation, user experience, transparency and value.

But ultimately, fintech startups and Wall Street giants played nice. Many financial services companies saw the writing on the wall and decided that if they couldn't move quickly enough to incubate those innovations in-house, they could join forces with newcomers through strategic partnerships. It turned out this was the beginning of a mutually beneficial friendship, resulting in a huge win for consumers.

In 2015, Jamie Dimon gave his ominous warning that "Silicon Valley is coming." Wall Street was able to weather the storm in subsequent years, but they're not out of the woods.

With a deep user base, tech looms large

For Wall Street, Big Tech poses a threat to financial services that is, well, bigger. Amazon, Apple and Alphabet-currently the second, third and fourth largest companies in the United States-have something that the small fintech start-ups lack: Scale. A lot of it.

If Fintech 1.0 was all about plucky startups working to elevate the standards that consumers expected from financial services companies, Fintech 2.0 is about Silicon Valley behemoths turbocharging that mindset with the backing of billions of dollars of capital.

These companies bring to the table the best cloud, data and AI resources on the planet. No one knows better than these giants how to surround a customer with an experience so seamlessly connected that the ease of use is worth the sacrifice of privacy (something traditional financial firms have struggled to deliver).

This is, in part, because most tech players have kept reputations as friendly giants. Their Net Promoter Scores soar high above big banks. People are willing to give a company like Google all their information if it makes it easy to toggle between their laptop, their phone and an IoT device. What if Google's deep data troves could give you a holistic view of your financial picture too?

What does this mean for Wall Street? The bar for best-in-class UX is about to be raised again.

2020 could impact competition

Regulatory headwinds could slow Big Tech's penetration into finance. Just last month, Congress made moves to stymie Facebook and friends from launching their take on a cryptocurrency, Libra, with the aptly named "Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act." And, in the first Democratic debate, Senator Elizabeth Warren called for the breakup of America's largest tech players. With an election coming, it remains to be seen whether the House and Senate will turn red, purple or blue. But the parties in power will influence the future role that Big Tech can play in the financial services ecosystem.

Regardless of how things evolve, in the early innings of Fintech 2.0, Big Tech has changed the game.

The future of financial marketing comms

Let's face it: Wall Street and Silicon Valley come from very different marketing communications schools of thought. As they square off to fight for share of wallet, there are marketing and communications lessons that Wall Street and Silicon Valley can learn from one another.

Dear Big Tech, don't forget thought leadership: In the years following the Financial Crisis, finance became commoditized-in product and cost-and the best way to win customer trust was in a race to capture share-of-voice through thought leadership.

Big firms launched thought leadership programs-often composed of a combination of proprietary research, earned media, content, and social/digital activations-that dug into consumers' emotional relationships with money, explored the role gender dynamics plays in investing and provided the tips to help people navigate financial decisions. Part group therapy, part actionable financial insights, consumer finance marketing communications became more human. This financial expertise and thought leadership is what sets traditional financial players apart from tech giants.

As Big Tech matures in the financial services realm, it could stand to take a leaf out of Wall Street's book, by going to market above product, addressing consumers' real desire for financial tips, education and empathy.

Wall Street, it's time to evolve your value prop: Wall Street also has a lesson to learn from Silicon Valley.

If Big Tech knows how to do one thing, it's to cultivate a user experience that is simple, well-designed and engaging. As these tech players dive fully into the financial services competitor set, customer expectations for user interface, PFM, smart analytics and AI are about to climb yet again.

In order to continue to thrive, traditional financial players will need to prove that they can match their counterparts in cultivating a compelling user experience that centers around an excellent product. As tech players challenge traditional financial models, Wall Street will need to make sure they're focusing on price, product and innovation as much as their competition is.

Wall Street has shown itself to be resilient and-by and large-willing to evolve to keep up with their customers' expectations. If they can continue to lead the way in financial thought leadership while delivering on UX, they stand in good stead for the future.

The financial services marketplace is entering a second wave of rapid evolution. But if Wall Street and Silicon Valley can learn a little from each other, then, ultimately, the end user will come out on top.

urn:contentItem:5TNH-0111-DYNS-30V7-00000-00Wall Street, Big Tech Bet on #BlueWave2018-11-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSWall Street, Big Tech Bet on #BlueWaveKate PatrickInsideSources.com, Washington, D.C.

Nov. 05--Wall Street and Big Tech are betting on a #BlueWave overtaking the House this year as they continue to give more to Democratic candidates than Republicans just days before midterms.

POLITICO reported recently that Silicon Valley has given $13.4 million to Democrats but only $3.4 million to Republicans, which means Democrats are getting almost triple that of Republicans. POLITICO also reported that more than 90 percent of staff donations from major tech firms like Alphabet, Apple, eBay, Facebook, Netflix and Twitter went to Democratic candidates.

And it's not just Big Tech: despite Democrats' tendency to distrust Wall Street and call for more financial regulation, big Wall Street donors are giving more to Democrats than Republicans this year, according to a New York Times report.

If Democrats take the House, Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) will likely become chairwoman of the House Financial Services Committee. As a consistently outspoken critic of Wall Street and a proponent of stricter Wall Street regulations, some industry players fear she will crack down on them if they don't get on her good side now.

While Democrats are more prone than ever to heavily regulate Silicon Valley and Wall Street given the recent string of scandals at Facebook and Google over privacy concerns and Democrats' persistent distrust of the finance industry, backing Democrats now could be a way to mitigate some of the regulatory damage.

Tech and telecom firms have acknowledged in recent hearings that the U.S. needs some form of federal privacy standard, and various companies like AT&T and Alphabet have told Congress they are willing to work with them on legislation that works for everyone.

Silicon Valley is especially wary of consumer advocates swaying Congress -- consumer-focused legislation in the European Union (EU), for example, like the GDPR and updated Copyright Directive, are extremely unpopular among U.S. tech companies.

That said, donating to candidates most likely to win could help tech companies -- and finance companies -- maintain some influence over the next round of tech regulations.

"Money gets you access," said Lawrence White, professor of economics at New York University's Leonard N. Stern School of Business. "Even if it comes a Democratic Congress, and there's financial reform regulation on the table, the Wall Street guys want to be able to talk to the staff of the Senate Banking Committee and the House Financial Services Committee,and just point out, here are the implications [from our end]."

The number of donations going to Democrats has less to do with who Wall Street and Silicon want in office and more to do with how they think midterms will go, he said.

In other words, they're betting on a "Blue Wave."

"My guess is that's what they're predicting," he told InsideSources. "The question of whether Maxine Waters becomes chair of the committee is an interesting one, that would be less than ideal from the Wall Street perspective. But Waters has to carry her committee with her. The chair has a lot of power, no question about that, but she has to carry her committee with her. Having the ability to talk to people at the end of the day is really what it's all about."

Investors hope the new week isn't a repeat of the last, chaos or calm? No matter, Some hot hands look at where investors should be putting their money now. Also the deadly crash of a Marine aircraft prompts the Pentagon to take action, as investigators search for clues. Next, the popularity of on-line trading is exploding in Asia. It could mean big investment opportunities for U.S. investors. Finally, Mary Farrell, a top investment strategist for PaineWebber, discusses her new book, "Beyond the Basics: How to Invest Your Money, Now That You Know a Thing or Two."

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN ANCHOR: Investors hope the new week isn't a repeat of the last, chaos or calm? No matter, we asked some hot hands where you should be putting your money now.

BILL TUCKER, CNN ANCHOR: The deadly crash of a Marine aircraft prompts the Pentagon to take action, as investigators search for clues. We'll have a live report.

KEENAN: We asked, you answered. We will tell you which stocks viewers voted out of the IN THE MONEY portfolio and where that leaves our collection of stocks.

TUCKER: The popularity of on-line trading is exploding in Asia. It could mean big investment opportunities for U.S. investors. We'll tell you why.

ANNOUNCER: From CNN and CNNfn, this is IN THE MONEY with Terry Keenan, Bill Tucker, and Daryn Kagan.

TUCKER: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to IN THE MONEY.

KEENAN: And it is back to work Monday. We are all hoping, though, that we won't see an instant replay of last week's wild market ride. We have tips from lots of pros, and where you might want to put your money to work this week.

TUCKER: Today, so far, so good, Wall Street is rather calm this morning, as we head into the first busy week of the earnings season.

KEENAN: That's right. We have a whole slew of companies that are getting ready to release their numbers this week. We have GE, we have Time Warner, the parent of this networks, lots of tech stocks as well.

TUCKER: And then after the bell, we get Motorola, first big tech company to release its quarterly numbers today. Lots of stuff going on in market. We talk about, there is no volatility, there apparently is no volatility right now, but we did start out higher, and we have had both of these markets turn around, the Dow up, forging ahead though at the start of this week.

Well, for more on what's moving on Wall Street let's head down to the New York Stock Exchange and to Rhonda Schaffler.

Rhonda, what's driving the Dow?

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, there, Bill, Terry.

Well, you know, there is a lot of components within the Dow, racing higher here. There has been a move today, at least, back into some of those old-economy stocks, as the techs sell-off. And in fact, one Merrill Lynch strategist talked up that fact in a research note out today that perhaps investors should cut their exposure to techs and move into some of these old-economy stocks. And within the Dow, the best performing group are financial stocks, and it is the same for here on the Big Board, huge gains in some of the financial stocks, including the financial components within the Dow, American Express and J.P. Morgan. We are seeing gains in brokerage firms, too, such as Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers, Charles Schwab.

One reason for this is, there is a merger within that sector, and that is Wells Fargo, that stock is little changed at the moment. It is merging with First Security in a deal valued at just over $3 billion. Wells Fargo based in San Francisco, and the bank that it is acquiring is based in Utah.

The fact that there is a merger is being talked up here, and it is cited as one reason why there is a lot of buying in the financial stocks today.

TUCKER: Motorola also catching a lot of people's attentions, Rhonda.

SCHAFFLER: Motorola was a big gainer on Friday. In fact, some of the strength we saw in chip stocks last week not continuing to the extent we are seeing today, but that company is due to report earnings. Motorola's stock has had an incredible run. It is not trading near its highs right now. It is about $30 away from its 52- week high. That stock was trading at about 70 a share, when it hit its 52-week low, due out with earnings today. OK, in our "E-World" segment today, we're looking at what could be a new frontier for the new economy. The popularity of online trading is exploding in Asia. Brokerage company stocks could reap many of the rewards of this latest craze in the Orient.

As Lian Pek explains, that could open the door to big investment opportunities for U.S. investors.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LIAN PEK, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Getting on the phone to your broker is still how most people in Asia trade stocks. But increasingly, the buy or sell order is just a mouse click away.

LANE LESKELA, GARTNER GROUP: The rate of growth of new online brokerage is quite phenomenon. In fact, by 2002, we actually expect that about 70 percent of all brokerages operating in markets like Australia, Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore will actually offer online trading.

PEK: South Korea is a case in point: Nearly 45 percent of retail trading is done through the Net. That's the highest cyber- trading penetration rate in the world. Even higher than that of the United States.

MARK DUFF, CEO, BOOM SECURITIES: The U.S. market took, really, between three and five years to evolve. We're seeing in Asia countries making the same evolutionary curve or adoption in a matter of six to nine months.

PEK: Not surprisingly, big-name U.S. brokers are flocking to the region. E*Trade is already muscling in on the lucrative Japanese market with E*Trade Japan, while Charles Schwab, America's largest e- broker, and second place TD Waterhouse, have started trading Hong Kong Shares.

KAREN BUCK, TD WATERHOUSE: One of the benefits that we will see of online trading, particularly here in Hong Kong as commissions are deregulated and straight-through processing takes place is that more firms will come into the market. We'll see a greater online penetration and customers will start to trade online, and also through wireless channels.

PEK: It's a growing industry, no doubt, but is there room enough for all? Boom Securities, the only pure online startup in Hong Kong, says local brokers are going for a different slice of the pie from their international counterparts. DUFF: The challenge to those institutions are the Merrill Lynches, Morgan Stanleys that have been out here for 15 to 20 years. They are, from our perspective, battling it out at 30,000 feet for the highest-income client. We're not in that bracket. We are a consumer product for a middle-income investor.

PEK: Even if there is enough business to go around, barriers to growth remain. Many countries sill have fixed commissions, and only a handful like Korea, Japan and Taiwan enjoy flexible rates.

(on camera): And when the regulating environment does eventually ease up, many predict the online floodgates should open. Not only will brokers get a better shot at those cyberspace profits, investors can also start trading for themselves, which means day-trading could become the next big thing in Asia.

Lian Pek, CNN Financial News, Hong Kong.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KEENAN: OK, let's take a look at how the online brokers are doing this morning. We have -- there you see a rally pretty much across the board, National Discount up 1 7/16, as is Charles Schwab. Fractional moves for E*Trade and DLJ Direct. And we have a big move for TD Waterhouse, as you can see there, Goldman Sachs adding that stock to its recommended list this morning.

TUCKER: There are, of course, many other things you can do online besides just trade. You can also pay your bills online. And we're going to take a look at paying your bills online in today's "E- World."

Several financial institutions now offer this service to clients. With a look at the options and the advantages of online bill-paying, we're joined now by Kelly Smith. She is the money editor for Time Warner's new monthly magazine called "Real Simple."

And welcome.

KELLY SMITH, MONEY EDITOR, "REAL SIMPLE": Good morning.

TUCKER: Good morning to you.

What is the deal here? And I ask with something of a personal interest because I've been looking at all of these various services. And one of the first things that comes to my mind is, are these services reliable and secure?

SMITH: Well, that's a big concern for a lot of people. I think a lot of people are intrigued by the idea of being able to simplify a task that's very time-consuming and reduce it down to 10 minutes. But privacy is a big issue. And so what you need to do, whether you're paying bills online through your bank or through one of the Internet bill-paying services that specializes in this in particular, you need to pay attention to what their stated privacy policy is. A lot of the banks will, you know, say that they will not share your direct information, but that they can share the information on how you use your banking account with their internal services to market products to you or services within the bank.

A lot of the Internet bill-paying services say that they won't share any information that can be traced directly to your customer account with anybody, whether it's in dealing with companies that they work with or trading lists or selling lists. Anything like that.

TUCKER: What about that difference between the bank and an online bill-paying service. Is one better than the other? Or how do you choose one?

SMITH: It depends on what kind of services you want. If you have a regular checking account with a bank, then it's fairly easy to set up a bill-paying online account with your bank. Basically, what you have to do is give them the names of your creditors and your account numbers and they will send -- when you get the bills each month, then you can direct your bank to pay those bills. You don't have to worry about stamps, you don't have to worry about making a trip to the post office.

But what the Internet bill-paying services like PayMyBills.com or StatusFactory or Paytrust.com, what they do is reroute your bills to them directly so you never actually get a paper bill. They'll send you an e-mail when your bill has arrived and you can either see a copy of it scanned in online and then direct the service to pay it or pay a portion of it or hold off.

TUCKER: What about fees?

SMITH: Well, these are actually very affordable. They can cost anywhere from nothing to about $10 for between 25 and 30 transactions a month.

TUCKER: All right, Kelly.

Kelly Smith. She is the editor of Time Warner's new magazine, "Real Simple."

Thank you for being here and being our guest on IN THE MONEY.

SMITH: You're welcome.

TUCKER: Now just ahead on IN THE MONEY, we're going to take a look at the markets. And PaineWebber's investment strategist Mary Farrell will be here to help you plan your stock investment strategies.

KEENAN: We're going to talk to her about her new book, up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

KEENAN: You are looking at a live pictures of the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, we are at our highs of the day for the Dow. Financial stocks and the pharmaceuticals are red hot this morning. We are seeing some selling in shares Hewlett Packard, though, that stock is down three.

TUCKER: Here on IN THE MONEY, we are always on the lookout for smart investment ideas that will help you make money. In today's "Moneywise" segment, we go beyond the basics with Mary Farrell.

KEENAN: You may know her as a top investment strategist for PaineWebber, she is a familiar face, she's been a regular guest here on IN THE MONEY talking about the markets and how you should invest. Today, she's joining us to talk about her book, "Beyond the Basics: How to Invest Your Money, Now That You Know a Thing or Two."

And Mary, welcome to IN THE MONEY. If you are an investor who knows a thing or two, but you know hasn't really be in the market for a long time, what's the most important thing that you should be doing right now?

MARY FARRELL, AUTHOR, "BEYOND THE BASICS": I think you really need to establish a financial plan, and that was why I wrote the book is the fact, while nearly 50 percent of Americans own stocks or mutual funds, but that is not the same as achieving your investment goals. You need to have both.

TUCKER: Well, we got a full screen of your basics, let's start with: "I know a thing or two" basics here and take a look at what we need to do. In the first thing you have up here, if you explain it to me, because I don't understand it, it is time in the market. What does that mean?

FARRELL: Well, I think we've seen a lot, particularly with a very volatile market, a lot of trading in and out of the market, and people are trying to be market timers to not get clinked by this volatility. But the real key to success is really time in the market. And I think very few investors, if any, can time the market successfully over time. So one of my strong recommendations is: Buy good quality companies that you are happy with over a multiyear period and hold on to them.

KEENAN: And what we've also learned in the market in the last couple of weeks is the virtues of diversification, right? And that is also one of your tips.

FARRELL: Yes, absolutely, and anyone who happened to own Internet stocks the last few weeks would realize why you should be diversified. But I think that's really important for investors, is certainly you want to have a chunk of technology, but you want to be sure that you are represented in a number of other areas, and that you should probably have some bonds, too, to be sure that you are not on the wrong side of the trend in the market.

TUCKER: One of my favorites of yours, in terms of advice, is once we have gotten beyond the basics is the "swan theory."

FARRELL: I had heard that expression at Swan Funds, and it is Sleep Well at Night Funds. But I think it is important because investors really need to assess their risk tolerance. You know, some investors can be 100 percent invested in technology stocks, be happy about it, ignore when they see Nasdaq moving a thousand points in a day, but there are some investors who can't sleep at night with that kind of investment, and they need to really structure a portfolio they are happy with.

KEENAN: One of your other "Beyond the Basics" there is to learn to pick stocks. That's not so easy. How do you start the process?

FARRELL: One thing I talk about extensively is what I call "thematic investing," because there a lot of things we don't know about what is going to happen. We don't know where the market is going to close this week or this month, but there is things we do know. We know technology is leading the economy. We know we are in an American age of affluence, where the baby boomers are in their peak spending years. So let's invest on the things we know, have that theme. And then, when you pick a stock, there's no shortcuts, you have to understand the company, why you are buying it, understand their competitors, and really make a fundamental assessment of what their earnings growth is going to be.

TUCKER: Once you know a thing or two, you know a thing two or three, and I'm wondering where interest rates come into this picture because we have Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan determined to make interest rates part of our consciousness at least.

FARRELL: And that's part of the process of education. In some ways, we've been very fortunate because this has been the most extraordinary bull market in history, and I think that's immunized people to the potential risks you have, if interest rates rise. You know, we have been declining rates since '82, so now that's firmly in place. But if they started rising again, that would certainly mean you would have to invest differently.

Fortunately, I think, even though they backed up a bit, I think the long-term trend remains in place that they will continue moving down.

KEENAN: And when it comes to mutual funds, you are not an overwhelming proponent of mutual funds. Do you believe that you should use them when you get your investment goals accomplished elsewhere, right?

FARRELL: I think there is very strategic uses for mutual funds, and one of the best uses -- you know, so many people are afraid to take that initial plunge into the market because they don't have enough money for a diversified portfolio, you are buying a diversified portfolio with professional management when you buy a mutual funds at a very cheap price. I think it is a great way to start the market.

And then a great way to give you participation. If you want to buy foreign stocks, for example, it's very difficult for an individual to buy foreign stocks directly, a fund can give you that, or if you want exposure in a particular sector.

And then there is group of people who really don't want to invest the time or effort to be involved with their portfolio, and then a good balanced fund is a good way for them to get that professional management.

TUCKER: With these markets like they've been lately, Mary, what do you make of them? Are we just in a hiccup here or are we OK?

FARRELL: I think, unfortunately, we are going to continue to see this volatility, and part of the problem is that we do have these day traders chasing momentum, that tends to exacerbate the move, you have the on-line traders who trade very quickly and cheaply, and studies show they trade more often. So i think you are going to see these bounces moving around.

I think the important thing is, it doesn't change the long-term trend. You know, when you are buying a company, you are buying a future stream of earnings, and that usually is not affected by the short-term volatility.

TUCKER: Excellent, Mary, thank you very much.

KEENAN: Thanks, Mary, congratulations on the book.

FARRELL: Thank you.

KEENAN: Mary Farrell.

That does it for today's edition of IN THE MONEY. Thanks for watching. I'm Terry Keenan.

TUCKER: We'll see you tomorrow.

urn:contentItem:3TDD-T710-009B-G11X-00000-00Wall Street Closes Busiest Trading Week Ever1996-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisMoneyline 7:00 pm ETBusinessShow; News Item1724Wall Street Closes Busiest Trading Week EverLOU DOBBS;

Today closed the busiest trading week on Wall Street ever, and some indexes managed to show a bit of a gain after Monday's spectacular plunge. Some believe this is a great time for bargain hunters.

LOU DOBBS, Anchor: Good evening. Wall Street today wrapping up its busiest week ever - a stunning 5-1/2 billion shares were traded on the big board and the NASDAQ this week. It was also a week of wild price swings although today the direction was decidedly lower, continued weakness in technology issues and concerns about corporate profits once again moving into the marketplace to hurt stock prices. At the close tonight, the Dow Jones Industrials 5,426.82, a loss of 37.36 on the day.
 
Big board volume slowed to 408 million shares despite double witching, exploration of options and futures. For the week, the Dow Jones Industrials down a modest 83.74. The NASDAQ fell 12.14 today after surging 56 points over the past two days. The volume on the NASDAQ - 531 million shares, almost 532 million. And bond prices losing ground after yesterday's big run up. The 30-year bond lost more than half a point in price today and the yield rose to 6.97 percent. Not exactly a dull summer so far on Wall Street. Greg Clarkin has been following the market mayhem and is here tonight with a report.
 
GREG CLARKIN, CNN Financial News Correspondent: Well, Lou, as the market as week that Roth Walsh did. Records were shattered. Investor confidence was robbed and when the dust cleared, investor wanted to know if the turmoil was really over.

From the Chicago's Future's pits to the New York Stock Exchange, it was a week of worry in the markets and resignation among average investors.
 
1st MARKET INVESTOR: I'm not nervous about it. I just think it's a natural thing that happens in a market.
 
2nd MARKET INVESTOR: I don't get nervous. In the long run everything- if the economy is good, the market will be good.
 
GREG CLARKIN: A 161-point loss on the Dow on Monday was followed by a whipsaw session Tuesday when a record billion-and-a-half shares traded on the NYSE and NASDAQ and the Dow swung from a 167-point loss to a slight gain.
 
RICHARD GRASSO, Chairman, NYSE: This is our most active week in our history. We'll trade 2.4 and a fraction billion shares and that, of course, for us a few short years ago was a great year.
 
GREG CLARKIN: Four earnings reports triggered the selling and sparked fears that the long-running bull market had stalled.
 
GAIL DUDACK, Chief Investment Strategist, UBS Securities: It's very obvious that corporate earnings for the S&P will not be better than that GDP growth that we're seeing. And that, I think, is the big surprise on the earning's front.
 
GREG CLARKIN: But the sell off blew off by week's end. Solid earnings from NASDAQ bell weather Intel helped restore stability and investor confidence. Stocks soared late in the week but never recovered completely. Some said the market moved through a quick correction.
 
LARRY RICE, Chief Market Strategist, Josephthal Lyon & Ross: I think we're very close to the end of this particular correction. The bull market is not over by any means. You need several increases in interest rates before stocks top out.
 
GREG CLARKIN: And the Federal Reserve chairman gave investors hope Thursday that a rate hike will not come soon.
 
Now, market optimists may say that all this selling has created a bargain-hunter's paradise. But, Lou, there are plenty of market pros who will tell that there are still companies that over-valued stocks and that their primed for a fall.
 
LOU DOBBS: So, we've got some over-valued and under-valued.
 
GREG CLARKIN: Exactly.
 
LOU DOBBS: Sounds like a market. All right, Greg. Thanks.
 
Well, as we reported, technology stocks today pulled back. The next big tech report comes Monday after the close when Microsoft posts its second-quarter results.
 
RICK SHERLUND, Technology Analyst, Goldman Sachs: Microsoft is having a very good quarter. We're looking for revenues up about 35 percent and I think it could be a little better than that possibly. So, I think we'll see very good results from Microsoft. What will be most important is the commentary, what the outlook is for the second half of this year.
 
LOU DOBBS: Microsoft today moving up almost 1-1/8 ahead of that earnings report and among other techs whose results simply weren't enough for this street, I-Omega [sp] today tumbling five-and-a-half dollars a share, losing almost 20 percent of its price, 18 million shares were traded; that despite a five-fold surge and quarterly revenue. Some microsystems down almost three-and-a-half dollars. Netscape [sp] down three and a half.
 
FTC Forced to Rethink Its Role as Telecom Changes
 
LOU DOBBS, Anchor: Another step forward tonight, however, for the merger of Time Warner and CNN's parent company Turner Broadcasting. The FTC has told its staff to draft a final-consent order that would clear the deal. Commissioners will formally vote when that draft is complete. That's expected within the next three weeks. Kelli Arena is in Washington and has the story for us.
 
KELLI ARENA, Correspondent: The Federal Trade Commission does not welcome a lot of attention. But its been closely watched during the Turner-Time Warner merger process.
 
Antitrust lawyers and merger experts say they were most impressed at how the FTC showed a great deal of flexibility. With the passage of the Telecommunications Act, observers say it's vital that the FTC carves out a role for itself.
 
SCOTT CLELAND, Telecommunications Analyst, Washington Research Group: Without a doubt, the 1996 Telecom Act has by far a larger impact on the media industry than this deal. I would say this deal is the gnat on the back of- on the Telecom Act.
 
KELLI ARENA: As a result, veteran FTC watchers say they sense a 'C-change' at the agency. In an effort to remain an important player in media mergers, the FTC seems to have set aside its prosecutorial role, preferring instead to be more of a regulator. An example, the agency's detailed restructuring of the Time Warner-TBS deal.
 
DAVID DONOHOE, Antitrust Attorney: The idea of having fairly elaborate regulatory solutions is something which I think has been used much more frequently in the last two or three years than it had been before.
 
KELLI ARENA: Much of the credit for the transition is given to the FTC's chairman Robert Petovsky [sp] who was described as a mastermind when it comes to antitrust issues.
 
He also has a keen interest in media issues which could mean that the FTC will end up playing a larger role than the Justice Department in future media cases.
 
Kelli Arena, CNN Financial News, Washington.
 
LOU DOBBS: Well, Archer, Daniels, Midland tonight has cleared on legal hurdle. A federal judge in Chicago tonight has approved a $45 million settlement of a class action law suit brought against ADM. The company had been accused of fixing the price of Lycine [sp], a feed additive. ADM officials still face possible criminal charges in that case.
 
Quaker announcing a management shake up at its faltering Snapple beverage unit, a three-man team replacing the unit's president Donald Uzzi [sp] who is leaving the company. This new team of managers to report directly to Quaker chairman William Smithburg. Quaker running into nothing but trouble since paying $1.7 billion for Snapple back in 1994.
 
A major executive change triggering a stunning rally in Sunbeam shares. Sunbeam stock up 24 percent in price today, gaining 6-1/8 a share. Investors euphoric about the company's choice for chairman and chief executive officer. Sunbeam hired cost-cutter with Ampier [sp] Albert Dunlap to boost it's lodging earnings and performance. The former chief executive office of Scott Paper revived that company with sweeping job cuts earning the title 'Chainsaw Al.' Dunlap pocketed $100 million when Scott was sold to Kimberly-Clark last year and Dunlap isn't doing too badly in his first full day at Sunbeam.
 
Dunlap yesterday bought three million shares of Sunbeam and that has netted him a profit of $1.6 million with that $6.00 surge in the price of Sunbeam shares.
 
Well, coming up next here on Moneyline we'll take a closer look at the day's activity on Wall Street - the big losers, the winners and the rising level of insider sales. What does it mean to top executives all over the countries dumping shares into their companies. We'll take a look at the reasons why. Stay with us.
 
Insider Selling at Record High Levels, Worrying Some
 
LOU DOBBS, Anchor: Well, a volatile week on Wall Street, and today tech stocks pulled back from what has been a two-day rally. The Dow tonight at 5426.82, down 37.36 on the day. For the week, down almost 84 points, and it didn't seem possible that it could do that well as the week began. Volume 408 million shares. Declining issues today beat out advancers by a three-to-two margin.
 
The Composite fell 2.19, the S&P 500 down 4.83. And, with the airline sector down sharply, the Dow transports fell 13.13 and the utilities, on a modestly weaker bond market, falling significantly - down 1.89.
 
The Nasdaq Composite - 1097.68 at the close, losing 12.14. The Nasdaq this week, after all of the dust and smoke had settled, losing only six points. Almost 532 million shares were traded today. Decliners beat advancers on the Nasdaq by almost 400 shares today. The American Exchange Composite - 548.76 at the close of business, losing 2.87 and volume more than 19 million shares.
 
Tonight's moneyline movers led by Delta, which dropped 2 1/8th. Fourth quarter earnings down 36 percent. That because of a one-time charge to pay for its early retirement program. Without that charge, profits would have risen 31 percent.
 
America Online gained $2.75 a share. America Online says it expects to at least double fourth quarter earnings. Amgen gaining almost a dollar a share. Second quarter profits there up 30 percent. Amgen also expecting double-digit sales growth over the next few years.
 
Gillette gained $2.50 today. Second quarter earnings of
 
Gillette up 19 percent. The company also acquiring a Russian razor maker. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.
 
Invision Technologies surged 4 1/8th. The company makes a machine called CTX-5000, which detects explosive devices in luggage. That stock moving up, following the devastating TWA crash Wednesday. Second quarter earnings exceeded Wall Street expectations. Flouriscan [sp] Imaging Systems surging 2 7/8th or 37 percent. Hollogic [sp] acquiring the x-ray equipment maker.
 
In other corporate news, General Mills- General Mills launching two low-fat breakfast cereals under the Betty Crocker brand name. Betty Crocker, of course, best known for cakes and other desserts.
 
Roadmaster Industries selling its bicycle and Flexible Flyers sled business to Brunswick. The price - $212 million. And, Ryder hiring Golden-Sachs to explore the sale of its consumer truck rental unit. Ryder today gained 5/8ths.
 
Not everyone was caught off guard when the stock markets lurched lower earlier this week. Insider trading- insider selling, rather, or the selling by senior executives, has risen sharply over the past few weeks. Some analysts say that's a sign the market could be headed lower. Sean Callebs has the report.
 
SEAN CALLEBS, Correspondent: America Online, Micron [sp] Tech, Seagate [sp], Filenet [sp], Sunglass [unintelligible] International and Bright Point [sp] - all companies that took a beating in the big sell-off. But, some officers of those companies apparently escaped before the fall. Analysts following insider deals report an unusually high amount of selling over the past several weeks.
 
DAVID COLEMAN, Vickers Weekly, Insider Report: Patterns of executives and directors are often telling indicators to a stock's future performance. The management of a company is- are the individuals who are down in the trenches and the best indicator that I've ever seen.
 
SEAN CALLEBS: Officers buying and selling chunks of their stock must file reports with the government. Often executives sell when they believe the price has topped out, or when future earnings prospects may be poor. And, those sales are at a record level. Analysts who track inside selling say that since the start of the year, insiders are selling stocks more than twice as often as other insiders are buying.
 
LARRY RICE, Investment Strategist, Josephthal Lyon & Ross: You've got the end of the bull market. Whether you're in the 7th inning or the 8th inning, you're late in the game. But, certainly the bear market has not begun, but we're in this corrective phase.
 
SEAN CALLEBS: Analysts say insider selling is broad-based, in industries from data processing to automotive manufacturing. And, they say, the only really insider buying going on right now is in real estate.
 
The selling trend doesn't necessarily mean that a bear market is just around the corner. Experts caution that insiders sell for a number of reasons - sometimes they just need the money. But, a trend of this magnitude does have some analysts concerned that the correction isn't over just yet.
 
Sean Callebs, CNN Financial News, New York.
 
LOU DOBBS: Westinghouse today announcing plans - very sketchy plans - to launch what they are terming 'a news-related cable channel.' Westinghouse Chairman Michael Jordan, says the channel will be, 'news-related, but not a news channel'. A lot of executives at a number of networks are trying to figure out exactly what that means tonight. Westinghouse shares today down 50 cents. Westinghouse closed at 17 1/8th.
 
In announcing those plans late today, Jordan stressed he has no interest in the movie business. Jordan saying, 'You might as well go to Las Vegas.'
 
Coming up next here on Moneyline, a whirlwind of a week in the markets. We'll have one of the country's top strategist telling us what it all means and what we can expect. My guest tonight is Bill Dodge of Marvin & Palmer. Stay with us.
 
Dodge Recommends International Market Investments
 
LOU DOBBS, Anchor: Well, a relatively quiet ending to what has been at least a stomach churning week on Wall Street. Joining me now to put the week's price swings in perspective is Bill Dodge, Chief Investment Strategist at Marvin & Palmer. Bill oversees, by the way, $3.5 billion at the global money management firm. Good to have you with us.
 
BILL DODGE, Chief Investment Strategist, Marvin & Palmer: Good to be here.
 
LOU DOBBS: Now, let me ask you, you know, when you look at the- the Nasdaq only losing six points on the week after the way we began, I- are you as surprised as I am that that's the size of the swing?
 
BILL DODGE: Yeah, I'm surprised at the volatility. I'm surprised we came back as quickly as we did, and, yet, I'm not. In the context that the- the money flows are still strong into mutual funds, and that's the real key to what's been going and what's going to happen. So, the buying power continues to come in.
 
LOU DOBBS: The buying power is there. Is this volatility at an end, are we watching its ebb, or what can we expect?
 
BILL DODGE: I think we're going to stay in a rather tight 5-600 point trading range. It's going to be volatile. It's going to be tough for the U.S. market to- to perform like it has in the last few years. And, I would not expect it to break out to the upside in a major move here throughout the year, frankly, although we can trade back towards 57 or 58 hundred.
 
LOU DOBBS: Now, a lot of people, as you know, are talking about a fundamental shift in investor psychology here. We've gone from concerns about inflation and an overheated economy to concerns about a lack of earnings and the prospect of recession. Tell us what you think.
 
BILL DODGE: Well, money flows dropped from $25 billion last- in May to $15 in June. It's all over. It has to have peaked. Well, the bottom line is this has been driven by generational demographics and a profound change in the competitive position of U.S. corporations, as exports have risen from five percent of GDP to nearly 20 percent of GDP.
 
Both those fundamental trends are still in place. Particularly, the generational demographics have another 10 years to go, and so I think this bull market's got a lot left in it. From a longer term- point of view, this is not the end of this secular or great disinflation bull market by any means at all. It's taken a time out after a period of going hyperbolic, I think is what the press liked to call it last year.
 
LOU DOBBS: Well, we have seen some stunning gains. I mean, we're still up significantly on these indexes despite all of the volatility and downside moves over the last two weeks. You- you think this correction is at an end?
 
BILL DODGE: I think the-
 
LOU DOBBS: Is this a correction? I guess I should first start out - is this a correction?
 
BILL DODGE: Well, sure, it is. Absolutely qualifies for an intermediate term, a minor correction. It's not a severe correction. I think it could get to the 12-13 percent level. I would say 5000 on the Dow, 1000 on the Nasdaq Composite, 600 on the S&P could be the low. We may have- we may have seen it.
 
We're not going to straight up. Today's, you know, clear indication of that. We're going to repair the damage. The psychology has been broken. There's been some pocketbooks broken in the aggressive growth areas, and people are going to search around, I think, for new places to- to put their money. It's going to keep coming in though.
 
LOU DOBBS: That- that money, that liquidity-
 
BILL DODGE: Yeah.
 
LOU DOBBS: -is critically important, irrespective of the- of the fundamentals.
 
BILL DODGE: Absolutely.
 
LOU DOBBS: But, the- Sean Callebs just did the report on inside-
 
BILL DODGE: Right.
 
LOU DOBBS: -insider selling. How important is that to you in your evaluation of the market?
 
BILL DODGE: Well, it can be- I think it can be very important at the company level. At major turning points, I suppose it can be extreme and be indicative of a trend. But, we always will have to keep in mind that over the past five or 10 years, stock options and stock incentive programs, of one form or another, have become a major portion of CEO and senior management and middle management - and farther down in the corporation, frankly - compensation. Incentive compensation is a- is a major factor that will influence insiders selling from time to time.
 
LOU DOBBS: So, you don't see this as particularly pronounced or indicative of much at this point?
 
BILL DODGE: No, I don't. I- I really don't.
 
LOU DOBBS: Now, you talked about where we put our money. Let's- let's talk about where we put our money. What do we do? Is this a market in which to invest?
 
BILL DODGE: Well, the trouble the market has is interest rates. The U.S. economy and the rest of the major economies - Japan and Germany in particular - are starting to grow. We haven't had that happen for a decade. That means interest rates are going to be pressured over the next year, year-and-a-half or maybe two years. So, you want to find things that are going to do well from an earnings point of view - that's U.S. industrials.
 
And, I think, frankly, if you're looking for value and maybe relative growth over the next couple years, it's probably in the foreign markets. In emerging markets you can get almost- You're paying almost twice as much in the U.S. for a unit of growth, for example, in emerging markets and almost 40 percent more in those international markets that are not really the emerging markets. So, I think there's a shift that's begun and this is a good time for U.S. investors to add to that international allocation, frankly.
 
LOU DOBBS: And, the two past two weeks in U.S. markets has been a pretty good pre-conditioner and training ground for investment in some of those sometimes very volatile emerging markets.
 
BILL DODGE: We've had one heck of a five-year relative run for the U.S. market, and I think, yes, people are starting to say maybe we should be looking elsewhere. Yes.
 
LOU DOBBS: All right. Bill Dodge, as always, great to have you with us.
 
BILL DODGE: Thank you.
 
LOU DOBBS: Come back soon. Well, coming up next here on Moneyline - let the marketing games begin. Two rival sneaker makers shell out lots of money in a battle for Olympic gold. Stay with us.
 
Nike Engages in Ambush Advertising of Olympian Size
 
LOU DOBBS, Anchor: In Atlanta tonight, opening ceremonies for the Summer Olympics. The games begin tomorrow. A fierce marketing battle is already underway. Reebok, an official Olympic sponsor pitted against Nike, which has literally ambushed its way into the Olympic Games. Rhonda Schaeffler has the story.
 
RHONDA SCHAEFFLER, Correspondent: Atlanta's been inundated by athletes, tourists and a Nike Swoosh. It's on billboards, on a specially-constructed Nike building overlooking the Olympic Park, not to mention on the hearts and soles of thousands of Olympic competitors. Never Mind that Nike is not the official Olympic footwear supplier. Reebok is.
 
SEAN BRENNER, Editor, Team Marketing Report: As far as whether it's going to hurt Reebok- it will certainly take some of the attention away that Reebok could have gotten.
 
RHONDA SCHAEFFLER: Nike is going for the gold in a new unsanctioned event - ambush marketing, associating itself with the Summer Games even though it has no official Olympic role.
 
Reebok paid $20 million for the right to advertise during network Olympic coverage. Nike counters with a blitz of ads outside Olympic coverage. Nike can't use the word Olympics, but its ad showcased top Olympic athletes like Carl Lewis. Nike easily outsells Reebok the world over and its summer ad blitz will make it tougher for Reebok to close the gap.
 
FRANK VUONO, Pres., Integrated Sports, Intl.: It may take more than what Reebok's willing to put in after they've spent the millions of dollars they've spent for their official association and after they've spent all of their marketing dollars in this particular effort, with Nike hammering away at them.
 
RHONDA SCHAEFFLER: Reebok says its official Olympic role is worth the price because it boosts its image around the world. But around Atlanta, one of the most prominent images is that of the Swoosh that stole the sponsorship spotlight. Rhonda Schaeffler, CNN Financial News, New York.
 
LOU DOBBS: And that is Moneyline for this Friday evening. Thanks for being with us. Please join us Monday night when my guest will be John Hennesey, the chairman, chief executive officer of CS/First Boston. Until then, have a great weekend. I'm Lou Dobbs. Good night from New York.

urn:contentItem:60V8-0NY1-DYWP-8029-00000-00Wall Street closes out worst week in months2020-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisBPg. 5Wall Street closes out worst week in monthsThe Associated Press

The Associated Press

NEW YORK - Wall Street closed out its worst week since June with another day of churning trading Friday, as big technology stocks resumed their suddenly weakened ways.

The S&P 500 rose 1.78, or 0.1%, to 3,340.97, but only after a roller-coaster day where a gain of 0.9% gave way to a loss of 0.9%. It kept swinging up and down after that, the latest examples of the lightning-quick shifts in momentum that have rocked Wall Street recently. Through the tumultuous week, the S&P 500 lost 2.5% to clinch its first back-to-back weekly loss in four months.

The Nasdaq composite, which includes many of the superstar tech stocks that have been the focus of the market's recent selling, lost 66.05, or 0.6%, to 10,853.55 after also flip-flopping between gains and losses. Its 4.1% drop for the week was its worst since market panic was peaking about the coronavirus and stocks hit a bottom in late March.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 131.06, or 0.5%, to 27,665.64, but not before careening between a gain of 294 points and a loss of 86 points.

Analysts expect swings to continue to rattle markets for weeks, if not months, as investors wait for more clarity on several key issues. At the head of the list of uncertainties is what to do with Big Tech stocks, which critics have long said were due for a slide after soaring too high through the summer.

"The technology sell-off continues," said Phil Orlando, chief equity market strategist at Federated Hermes. "We don't think this is anything more than a technical pullback that's cleansing. It's healthy and was anticipated."

Apple, Amazon and others soared through the pandemic as their businesses boomed despite the recession. The coronavirus accelerated a shift to online life that's benefited them, and a pile-on of investors into Big Tech sent their share prices soaring to levels that critics said were overvalued.

Apple had a nearly irrepressible run this summer where it rose in 12 out of 13 weeks. Zoom Video Communications surged above $450 per share earlier this month after starting the year at less than $70.

That all came to an abrupt halt last week. Worries that the stocks had gotten overheated helped send the S&P 500 to its worst three-day run in nearly three months, and the Nasdaq composite slid 10%. Tech stocks recovered a bit on Wednesday, and they seemed to regain their stride Thursday morning, only for an afternoon swoon to batter them again.

On Friday, tech stocks again swung from gains to losses. The fluctuations came even after Oracle reported stronger profit for its latest quarter than analysts expected. After leaping as much as 7.9% in the morning, its stock slipped 0.6%.

Big Tech and the high-growth area of the stock market "just got ahead of itself," said Jason Pride, chief investment officer of private wealth at Glenmede. "It doesn't matter how it got there, it matters that it got there and now we're kind of deflating that overvaluation a little bit."

After rising as much as 1.5% shortly after trading began, Apple fell back to a loss of 1.3%. It dropped 7.4% over the week, its worst since March. Movements for it and other Big Tech stocks matter more than ever for broad market indexes because their immense size means they can influence the S&P 500 almost by themselves. Five Big Tech companies make up nearly 23% of the index's entire value.

One big factor that remains in the stock market's favor is the Federal Reserve, which continues to pump aid into the economy. It has slashed short-term interest rates to record lows and bought up all kinds of bonds to support markets. It also said recently it will keep delivering stimulus even if inflation rises above its target level, as long as inflation had been well under it before then.

A report on Friday showed that inflation remains low, though it was higher than economists expected. Consumer prices rose 1.3% in August from a year earlier, a shade above the 1.2% that investors were expecting.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury slipped to 0.66% from 0.68% late Thursday.

Unprecedented amounts of aid from Congress, along with the Federal Reserve, also helped the stock market halt its nearly 34% plummet in late March.

But it looks less likely by the day that Congress will approve more support for the limping economy before the November elections, even though investors say such stimulus is crucial after unemployment benefits and other stimulus has expired. Senate Democrats on Thursday shot down a scaled-back package proposed by Republicans, saying it shortchanged too many needs.

Investors are also worried about all the uncertainty that elections bring generally, which can result in big changes for tax laws and regulations that affect corporate profits. Concerns are likewise high about trade tensions between the United States and China, among other major economies, and whether the expectations building for a coming COVID-19 vaccine prove to be too optimistic.

European stock markets made modest moves. The German DAX was close to flat, and the French CAC 40 rose 0.2%. The FTSE 100 in London rose 0.5%

Asian markets were stronger. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.7%, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong climbed 0.8% and stocks in Shanghai added 0.8%. The Kospi in South Korea was close to flat.

---

AP Business Writer Yuri Kageyama contributed.

urn:contentItem:60CJ-NKN1-JCMN-Y188-00000-00Wall Street drifts as S&P 500 nears another weekly gain2020-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:25ZLexisNexisWall Street drifts as S&P 500 nears another weekly gain

Jul 17, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) NEW YORK (AP) — Wall Street is drifting in early trading Friday, as the S&P 500 closes in on a third straight winning week. The benchmark index was up 0.1%, as of 9:55 a.m. Eastern time, following a mixed performance for stocks overseas. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 38 points, or 0.1%, at 26,772, and the Nasdaq composite was virtually flat.

Trading was relatively quiet across markets, with Treasury yields, gold and crude oil all making only modest moves. Even Chinese stocks were holding relatively steady: The Shanghai Composite index inched up just 0.1% following a run earlier this month where its average daily move was more than 2%. Most stocks across the U.S. market were higher, with homebuilders and construction-material companies helping to lead the way after a report showed a bigger jump in home construction during June than economists expected. PulteGroup rose 2%, and Lennar added 1.7%. Netflix fell 6.9% for the largest loss in the S&P 500 after its forecast for new subscribers during the summer fell short of Wall Street's own expectations, even though it reported stronger earnings for the spring than analysts expected. It's a relatively rare step down for Netflix, which is still up roughly 50% for 2020 so far. This week has seen some weakness for big tech-oriented stocks, which have been gliding higher through much of the pandemic on expectations that they can continue to grow almost regardless of the economy. The big run has critics saying they've become too expensive, even after accounting for the huge profits that they produce. Microsoft slipped another 0.8% Friday, while Apple dipped 0.1%. Tech stocks across the S&P 500 were down 0.1% in early trading, while internet and other communication-services stocks were down 0.7%. They were two of only three sectors in the S&P 500 that were lower. (Ad) In a form NS 43-101, two energy sector legends have told federal regulators that they may have found one of the world's biggest lithium discoveries - a massive 7 million tons near Tonopah, Nevada, worth around $70 billion. The S&P 500 is on track for a 1.1% rise for the week, though that would be the mildest in its three-week run. It's rallied back within 5% of its record set in February and is back to roughly where it was in early June. Pushing stocks up recently have been signs of improvement in the economy, along with rising hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine. Underlying it all is massive aid for the economy and the promise of ultralow interest rates from the Federal Reserve. But pulling stocks down at the same time have been worries about the continuing rise in coronavirus counts across the country, which threatens to derail the improvements. The yield on the 10-year Treasury held steady at 0.61%. In the commodities markets, gold added 0.5% to $1,809.40 per ounce. Benchmark U.S. crude oil inched up 5 cents to $40.98. Brent crude, the international standard, slipped 12 cents to $43.25 per barrel. In Europe, Germany's DAX returned 0.4%, and France's CAC 40 slipped 0.2%. The FTSE 100 in London added 0.6%. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.3%, South Korea's Kospi added 0.8% and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong rose 0.5%.6 Stocks to Help You Profit Off the Coronavirus PPE Boom[1]Every major global event brings with it changes to our national lexicon. Before the Covid-19 pandemic, few Americans knew what the initials PPE stood for. Today, virtually anyone knows that PPE stands for personal protective equipment. At the onset of the mitigation policies, the goal of flattening the curve was being done to prevent our health care system from becoming overwhelmed. Part of that concern stemmed from a shortage of personal protective equipment. These are the masks, gloves, goggles and gowns that help protect medical workers against viral or bacterial infections. As the novel coronavirus became labeled a global pandemic, the global mantra became to 'flatten the curve' in an effort to prevent our healthcare system from being overwhelmed. The United States is being referred to as being on a war time footing. Manufacturers that were already producing PPE have significantly ramped up capacity. And many companies are converting their excess manufacturing capacity to produce personal protective equipment.
